description.text:
This design was created as a step away from strictly "flat" parts and made to resemble a more organic feel. I need people to test this design, you may or may not need to slice the arms depending on your printer. Please print in ABS with the parts in their flattest face down. The elliptical arm should be supported and printed flat as well for maximum strength.
Some work may be needed for the fit of most parts but should be snug overall. Poll: Keep design current size or slightly smaller? UPDATES
Landing Gear temporary, rear "clip" will be replaced soon.
Tolerances for better fit and less problems on lower resolution printers.

comments.text: Printing one up right now.  The plate and front arms are done. Working on the cage halves. I have the luxury of a 12" build plate, so I am able to print the plate and cage halves each in one piece. I'll add the pics to the "I made one" section when it is complete, along with the print details.
comments.author: slowjoe170

comments.text: I am pleased to hear its going well, I have tested the design in PLA and it is more rigid, the front arms and plates would probably best suit PLA.
comments.author: slowjoe170

comments.text: Thanks for the reply. Had a time with the rear mount ellipse last night. I had to use rafts and support so it wouldn't pop off the bed. I actually like the size of it. True you'd need to have it to 250 specs for any type of 250 competition, but for weekend flying, like I do, the larger size allows more room for a camera, larger battery, and the other electronics to fit. I made a quicky set of front landing gear just to get it flight ready. Hope you don't mind. Looking forward to the landing gear design that you post for it. I'll try to get a photo or two of it in the "i made one" section this evening. Thanks again for making the design available.
comments.author: InEarthsOrbit

comments.text: If you check the updated front arms they have landing standoffs at the motors with updated and stronger motor mounts.
comments.author: slowjoe170

comments.text: Would love to test build this but the only thing i cant fit on my bed would be the front motor mounts
comments.author: Raidramon

comments.text: I will be updating the files in a few days with a split arms for printing in smaller beds. However this will significantly reduce the structural strength of their design.
comments.author: Raidramon

comments.text:
This is one awesome looking quad :) Looking for the landing gear - same style of course :)
I would only re-design the motor mount plates - flush the engines to the top surface and reinforce the bottom with some chamfers/blends - or in short just eliminate the sharp corners. A provision (holes, or struts) for FPV cam would be a nice addition.
comments.author: Japim

comments.text:
The design has been updated with a temporary fix but the redesigned landing gear will be modular so no mods will be required.
There are many FPV mounts and none are 100% standard. The flay surface and rails give a good amount of area to mount your specific camera.

description.text: Conventional finger skateboards may be the accepted present-day method of boarding with your fingers, but here on Thingiverse the future is now. Hop your digits onto this Finger Hoverboard, and float along in style! Not guaranteed to work over water.

The hoverboard in the photo was printed in Stone and Stellar Pink MakerBot ABS, "magnets" down, with a raft and support. If you keep an eye on the print, you can pause it and swap colors between the magnets and the board like I did. This was made without any traditional modelling software. I scaled the board from lsapozhnik's Finger Skateboard up to 100 mm long in MakerWare, then added some suitably scaled helper discs to serve as the magnets. I then exported that as a new STL and ran it through netfabb's cloud service which removed the screw holes and made the shape one solid piece.

description.text: Here are some of your favorite Comic Book Characters in mini figures. I promise there is more to come including more guys more accesories and maybe even a few vechicles. For now there is Hulk, Thor, Deapool, Green Arrow, Green Lantern, Galactus, Silver Surfer Batman and Joker. Please leave suggesitons down below for other characers I should make, but only one exception make them nerdy. (P.S. Marvel and D.C. will probably be the best.) https://youtu.be/HgqfCQY5StI

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

10%

Notes: Print most files with exterior supports that is crucial to the survival of your print. If your print has failed then you may need to boost up print infil to maybe 15% or more for better quality.

Design I like to take things from others and colage them within one piece So thanks to the people that made the designs I used to build these mini figs and please contact me if you would like one character or design. I also would like to thank Tinkercad.com. This is my editing site and where I make most of my designs, because I work on a chrome book and its an online program.

Hulk and Galactus  will be bigger and thus take more time and filament. This may also apply for some accesories. You will need to work on the clean up a lot. The more time you dedicate to the clean up the better it will be.

You can click the link above and you'll get to join my group and post your designs. Join us if you want to. We have very nerdy designs and geeky designs so come join us. Nerd's Ultimate the place to get all your nerdy props, cosplay and cool nerdy life hack prints. Don't be an anti social geek join the nerd army together we can be 1 million strong. So come on what do you have to lose nothing we nerds have a tendancy to flock together anyway, why not do it here to and remeber 1≈Geek 1≠Geek. 2 or more = Nerd ≠Geek Nerd > Geek h h

With some coffee ground, I observe some difficulties finding the balance when packing the coffee powder into the portafilter:   
When it's to packed, the machine clog, ... if it's not enough packed you get a "sock juice"!  
The solution : control the packing pressure !  
That's how I decide to design and print a Dynamometric coffee Tamper

The pressure is controlled with a spring located in the axis and is measured with the length of the axis.   
When pressing on the tamper, the spring collapse and the axis slide into the other, so the length reduces.  
The axis can be graduated to increase precision (not done on here).  
More you press, more the axis length is reduced, and more your coffee powder will be packed!  
The coil I have placed in allow me to apply a weight from 0 to approx 4kg.  
Picture of Description and code!  
The tamper is composed of 5 parts ... 4 of them are printable!  
The washer will block the upper axis into the lower axes.  
The upper axis is glued on the upper disk.  
The washer must be glued on the lower axis (after having inserted the spring!)

title: Tiny Boy Fabrikator 25mm feet to hold an 80mm fan in the center

description.text: Hi,  I was bored while waiting for solidworks to install so I made these feet up in sketchup which became pretty handy as the electronics and especially the stepper motor becomes really hot and skips steps..  with this printed plus an 80mm 12v fan,  she hasnt missed a beat.. takes about 1.2 hours to print per leg.  The G code included is from slic3r and is 30% speed on the first layer and 5% infill for the fastest possible print on these little bad boys...

remixed_from.author: kabe
remixed_from.title: Robo3D: Leadnut adapter with z-axis limit switch

title: Robo3D: Leadnut adapter with z-axis limit switch - 4 Hole remix

description.text:
I got my lead screws off ebay and the brass lead nut that came with it used 4 holes instead of 3. So i Just quickly edited the file. I only used two screws but left the holes for all 4 in case someone wanted them. Fits perfectly and I've been using for over a month with no problem. I've not added the auto-leveling switches so just refer to the original for help with that.  
Make sure you mirror one for the opposite side!  
Huge thanks to @kabe for the original design!

Scanned with ReconstructMe and an Xbox Kinect at the Coney Island Scan-A-Rama booth at Danbury Makerfaire on Saturday June 8, 2013. It was the public debut of my new scanning rig- the Scan-O-Tron 3000, and the scans have been beautiful. I am about to kick off a Kickstarter for Scan-A-Rama and plan to open source my plans, so stay tuned. Coney Island Scan-A-Rama is a next generation portrait studio for the 21st century! In the grand tradition of amusement part portraiture, but updated for the era of 3D printing, this popup 3D portrait studio will be appearing at MakerFaires and in Coney Island throughout 2013. For more information or to order prints, please visit http://www.thegreatfredini.com/scan-a-rama I recommend printing at .27 or .1 mm layer height with no support. You may have to trim a couple bits of hanging plastic off, but this will look great with no support.

This is a 100% printable filament spool based heavily upon randyy's design. Changes: Added webbing to arms for strength.
Modified dovetails for better fit (the original required a lot of sanding to get to fit well - for me).
Increased arm thickness for strength.
Increased mount size for strength and more solid connection to MakerBot.
Changed geometry of birdmouth slightly.
Increased size of filament holder so that more filament could be wound on spool.
Added hole in the filament holder.
Beefed up the filament clip on the filament holder.
Enlarged the conical pieces that press fit into the arm for more secure fit.
Added a filament guide for use with Cupcakes.

Print out and assemble. The dovetail parts should not need any trimming except for part that lies against the build platform. Even so, if you assemble it when it is warm you may not even need to do that. Wind the filament onto the spool. Start by threading the filament through the holes on the "U" shaped parts. Wind the filament so that it just lies gently in place. When you have finished loading the spool, cut the filament and then press the end of the filament into the built-in clips to keep it from unraveling. Mount the filament guide onto the cupcake just above the middle bolt as is shown in the picture. The clearance between the spool and the guide should be enough that you are sure that the spool won't hit it as it turns.
  • TOM filament guides available here; http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10335
    • Sketchup file is included.

comments.text: The spool hub was my first full size print after assembling my ToM Gen4 with Automated Build Platform, and I had a fair bit of trouble... The default outline is too big for the platform -- the print head would hit the bolt heads, so I made a new profile which disables the outline and edited the start.gcode to turn off the extruder after it does the "anchor" dot (otherwise you get a long thick line of plastic from the start point to the beginning of the raft). Be sure that your X-Y calibration is accurate because the raft will run right to the very edges!
comments.author: Joe

This a 100% printable Z stage bearing replacement upgrade.
It seemed that no matter how carefully I aligned the Z stage bearings - that when assembled into the Thing-O -Matic, the Z stage would chatter when lowering. In addition, there was some binding happening on the upward direction as well causing the Z axis to miss steps. 
The result of Z steps missed is apparent in the last picture. That piece worked well enough to fix the problem but a replacement was soon printed. Once it served it's purpose I stress tested it. It was surprisingly strong, taking far more effort to break than I expected. The parts are easily strong enough to support the Z stage, by far.
Another symptom of missed Z steps is the extruder skipping steps or stripping filament. If the Z axis fails to rise for the next layer then the nozzle will be too low and it is harder to push the filament out - resulting in filament stripping or the extruder skipping steps.
It was clear that the Z stage needed an upgrade but I really did not want to have to order bearings or search hardware stores for the right size brass tube, nor did I want to alter the machine in such a way that was  not reversible. Using plastic for the bearing surface may not seem to be a precision thing to do but as it turns out this has been highly reliable, repeatable and silky smooth. It is also designed in such a way that the bottom bearing surfaces contact the front of the rods and the top bearing surfaces contact the rear. This means that you can lift (tilt) the Z stage by about 10mm. This can be a useful feature when the nozzle accidentally crashes into a bolt head.
This may not work with an ABP due to clearance issues.

I designed this so that no modifications to the TOM are required. You only need to remove the original bearings and bolt in place. If you want to re-use the same bolts to attach the bottom pieces you will need to first draw the nuts down a bit further into the wood by over-tightening slightly. Otherwise, just use longer bolts.
Printed with .28mm layer height, 3 shells and 35% infill ( I think).
Use a cotton swab to put a small amount of lithium grease in where the rods contact the plastic.
Enjoy silky smooth and silent Z stage movement!

title: Game of Thrones Cyvasse board hexagonal 6x6x6x6x6x6

description.text:
When I saw the cyvasse game project I remembered that I saw too an hexagonal gameboard for this game. So here it is the 6x6x6x6x6x6 version of it. a) In 1 piece.
  • Print cyvasse_board.stl 1 time
  • Enjoy the game!!
    • b) In 6 parts
  • Print cyvasse_board_part1_x1.stl 1 time
  • Print cyvasse_board_part2_x5.stl 5 times
  • Setup it as in the image.
  • Enjoy the game!

Based on an hexagonal plate repeated in every position needed. You can find in the project the complete board and some parts to build it in small printers. title: uStepper linear actuator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Derivative of: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:45103 This is a compact derivative of the "Linear actuator concept for CNC machines" intended for stand-alone applications using a uStepper. Could be used as window or door opener for example. May be updated at a later point. Hardware:
2 x 625ZZ bearings
2 x M3x35mm
4 x M3x8mm (or M3x10mm if using washers)
1 x M3x10mm (for the motor gear)
3 x M3 nuts
2 x M5 nuts
1 x M5 threaded rod
2 x M5 washers (if needed between bearings and gear) A short video can be found here: https://youtu.be/LF4IwXSxZNg

Replacement forward lean block for a snowboard binding to replace a worn out and damaged part. Based on the worn out part taken off a pair of Union Bindings.

Print standing up on the flat end at 100% or 70% fill. The teeth will print great without  any support this way. Due to the small footprint, print with a large brim.  
Recommend abs for strength as this is a mechanical part that will have considerable forces imparted on it on hard heel-side turns, landings, etc. Pla seems to work fine as well, just probably wont last quite as long.

description.text:
3-13-2017 By popular demand, please find Rev 4 attached which now includes a hinge that will utilize 1.75mm filament as a pin for the new hinge. I also adjusted the angled part of the hinge system which should be easier to print without the need for supports. As always, comments or suggestions are always welcome! 5-5-2016
Happy Cinco de Mayo
I think this will be the final revision unless I receive feedback with revision requests.
Rev 3 change log
Removed material from top and bottom that will allow the model to print with WAY LESS supports. 3-14-2016
Happy pi day!
Rev 2 has been uploaded.
New items include:
Sd slots, 1 full and 2 micro cards supported
new bin for lens caps (hopefully)*
new hinge design that should snap together *I don't have any to grab dimensions off of. 10-21-2015
V2 of the bottom half has been updated with a notch for hold the wrench upright along with larger pegs to hold the gimbal shocks in place. To do: Still need to update the hinge to a better design, but it will work and keep closed. I recently printed this myself and the hinge is so thin that it doesn't hold the 2 halves together (it prints less than 180 degrees of contact). I will edit the model to fix this issue as soon as I can. This is a hinged case that will hold extra part for a DJI phantom drone. Gimbal shock absorbers, mounts, allen wrench, motor wrench, sd cards, prop guard screws, and more can all fit inside this case. Please leave comments and suggestions!

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

Whatever your comfortable with

comments.text: I had the same two comments, funny enough I was just going to comment those. The clip piece at the weakest point is only 2-3 layers max, plus they are stacked horizontally which puts the weak point in the layers not the piece itself. I had to glue the clip on 2 times before I remember to be extra careful with it. Additionally I found the micro SD card slot to be rather loose resulting in me searching my bag when it falls out, I solved this with a drop of glue to tighten the but it doesn't look very nice. I do love the case though! very nice to put that second battery slot in my bag to good use!

This is a printable strain relief for a Cupcake's HBP.

Print it, slide it onto the heated build platform. Zip tie the wires in place. Enjoy peace of mind that your wiring will last longer.
Note that it is sized to clamp onto the X stage platform with an aluminum heat spreader applied to the surface. The theory is that the aluminum underneath the HBP reflects heat back up to it, increasing efficiency. If you do not have that layer of aluminum then it will fit loosely. In that case you may want to add some tape to the surface before installing.

title: Pirates of the Caribbean Theme Song

description.text:
Make your 3D printer play music. Using the sounds a printer motor makes naturally its possible to convert a song into G-code that tells the printer to move along its axes in a way that creates a song. The provided G-code is for the Pirates of the Caribbean theme song. Here is a link to a video demonstration:
https://youtu.be/w1mBk1PRPgg

• Under the slicer configuration settings go to printer settings.
  • Under printer settings, select custom G-code.
  • Here you will insert the G-code on the next line after G28.
  • Save, and name the printer setting Pirates of the Caribbean.
  • Now when you load an object to print and are ready to slice it select Pirates of the Caribbean as you printer setting in the Slic3r menu.
  • Once you select start print the printer will home all axes and then begin playing while your extruder warms up! Before the song plays it will go to its starting position to verify the print bed dimensions. Once the song is done it will re-home all axes and then begin your print.
    • Note:
    The instructions demonstrate the use of this code using Repetier and Slic3r. I don't know how well it will work on other platforms. Caution:
    This code was generated to the dimensions of a printrbot simple's print bed. Given that this is a small four by four inch print bed there shouldn't be any points in the code that is out of range for most printers ,however, I do advise that you use it at your on risk. I would also like to give credit to HomeConstructor for the software I used to convert MIDI to g-code. Here is a link:
    http://en.homeconstructor.de/converter-convert-music-in-g-code.html

author: Davitosan

description.text:
This is my next homemade project for 3D printer.
Single homemade hotend or E3D compatible - 0,4 mm nozzle, bowden type extruder.
400W PC ATX PSU.
Electronics - Mega2560 + RAMPs 1,4 + Full_Graphic_Smart_LCD_Controller + 5 NEMA 17 motors. Malrin Fimware.
Expecting very small or none backlash effect with 5 mm rods for Z axis.
Working area with 220x200x3mm glass- XYZ - 220/186/148 mm;
Manual control for 40 mm fan for hotend/always ON by default/ and manual control for 30 mm fan duct with 500 oM potentiometer. Short video: https://youtu.be/aaMdQ0u-Osc Source files added for laser cutting and references (AutoCad 2010 or above). Also if You want to change ot remake anything. Clamp for E3D clone also is present in .stl files. Will do 30 mm fanduct for it soon.
I was close to start with leveling and calibration, but found some drama with the LCD. Probably, I have damaged it during the flash of the mainboard. So things won`t develope very fast, untill I replace it.
BOM ~270-275 € 20.09.2015
Uploaded 30 mm Fan Duct for E3D type hotend -> + 10 mm on Z print area.
Source files reuploaded + 2 pics with E3D type hotend look. 28.09.2015
Printer is leveled and calibrated. Waiting only for new LCD controler to complete it. Thing is final.
Will post video and pictures, when LCD is here (after ~2 weeks). 21.10.2015
New 2 pictures added with new lcd controller.
Link to video of secont test print - https://youtu.be/R7v5BBhPvtY
Test is made with the worst 1.75 mm ABS filament I have ever used - it is badly calibrated and got a lot of air bubbles. 0.2 mm layer hight
I got some things to improve mostly on print setting + got a layer shift on Y axis on the 3rd print test (some bridge test cube).
As it can be seen on the video no such thing as "massive Z wobble" here, on the contraty - You have to use expensive optic tools to see it :) 23.10.2015
Added photos of the result of the 3rd and last printer test - herringbone gears - at the end of the gallery. 0.2 mm layer hight, and better fillament used. A little bit to close start to table but the result is OK. It is ready and complete at 100%. There will not be any update anymore. 10.12.2015
Added patrs #32 and #33 on request.
Did upgrade of left and right X axis holders to fit for Tr8 leadscrew. It is for 4 hole nut (holes situated on 16.2 diameter of the nut - http://g04.a.alicdn.com/kf/HTB1hqsXKpXXXXb_XVXXq6xXFXXX2/3D-Printer-Part-THSL-300-8D-Lead-Screw-Rod-brass-nut-for-3D-Printer-.jpg). So, prepare additional 8 M3 nuts, 8 M3x12mm bolts and change the couplers to 5to8mm. 25.12.2016
Uploaded versions for Air2 3D printer for X axis. Distances between center of the nut and the vertical smooth rod for Z movement - 30.5 mm.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mx8ncfCHZms

comments.text: a prism is the most unstable geometric form. i suggest redesigning your frame. if you dont want massive z wobble.
comments.author: 3dNoScope

comments.text:
Well, thanks for the advice, but it is my 5th 3D printer and the 3rd with this design. I did nothing more, than replacing the side rods from standart RepRap design with solid MDF frames. And yes, the contruction is a lot stable than RepRap`s ones (my 1st and 2nd printers were with rods constructions).
Masive Z wooble is more connected with high speed, carriage weight + the hight ot the printer. This one has 50x42 cm base and 40 cm H. Speed limit 60 mm/s. From where this masive Z wooble will come?
